0: House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers warned Sunday there's "mounting evidence" that the Syrian government has been using its chemical arsenal. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I think when you look at the whole body of information over the last two years there is mounting evidence that it is probable that the Assad regime has used at least a small quantity of chemical weapons during the course of conflict," Rogers said on CBS's "Face the Nation." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Citing President Barack Obama's comments nearly a year ago that the use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government a "red line" for U.S. intervention, the Republican congressman from Michigan said it's "abundantly clear that red line has been crossed." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Now is the time. If we're going to have any hope for any diplomatic solution and stop that wholesale slaughter, some up to 70,000 and more in Syria which is now spilling up to the doorstep of Israel, it's causing huge problems in Jordan and Turkey," Rogers said. "This is a growing destabilizing event in the Middle East. The fact that they have I think put chemical weapons in position to use and I believe have intent and at some course during the last two years have used some quantity of chemical weapons this needs to be a game changer." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Speaking in Jerusalem last week, Obama said that if the Syrian military had used chemical weapons it would be a "game changer" with regard to American involvement in the civil war there. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Once we establish the facts, I have made clear that the use of chemical weapons is a game changer," Obama said in Jerusalem at a news conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The president went to the Middle East and said 'This is a hard decision. If I go in it might be wrong, if I don't go in it might be wrong.' Indecision in this case is dangerous to the United States," Rogers said, noting Obama's reluctance to involve American forces in support of forces opposing Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Rogers also warned that if the Assad regime is toppled, the region could dive into turmoil. "If Assad goes next week, this is mass chaos," he said.
